_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CHS Inc.



Risk Management Program Executive Summary



CHS is dedicated to preventing accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. The company stores

and distributes anhydrous ammonia in pressure vessels.



CHS believes that the health, safety, and preservation of our environment are critical components of

effective management and business success. As a company, we are committed to:

-Providing a secure and health conscious work environment for employees and visitors

-Conducting our business with always having value for the communities in which we operate and in

the spirit of a good neighbor

-Meeting or exceeding the requirements of the environmental, health, & safety laws and regulations

-Training employees on the environmental, health & safety requirements of their jobs

-Working with government and other stakeholders to identify and solve problems

-Anhydrous ammonia is stored in rail cars that are temporarily brought onto the property for a third

party vendor to use in a reaction process to make a liquid fertilizer blend.



The worst-case release scenario is created to show how far a plume of ammonia with a

concentration greater than 200 parts per million (PPM) would travel before being dispersed to a safe

exposure level.



A complete discharge of the railcar would be a very unusual event. We are also required to create

an alternative or more likely release event. Although we will continue to do what we can to ensure

no accidental release occurs, we have chosen a 2-inch pipe or hose rupture to meet this

requirement. Again, calculations show the extent of the plume with an ammonia concentration

greater than 200 PPM.



We have used RMP Comp to calculate the area these types of releases would impact. RMP Comp

is supplied to us by the EPA. It tends to over exaggerate the plume, which in turn adds a good

safety factor into the planning process. Our written programs are continually updated and are

available for review at the ammonia storage location

s.



In the event of a release from a rail car that could impact the community, we advise those in the

affected area to shelter in place until the plume dissipates. Shelter in place involves everyone in the

affected area seeking shelter indoors, shutting the windows and turning off the air conditioning and

other ventilation systems.



CHS operates over 100 ammonia storage sites across the country. In the past five years we have

had very few releases from fixed storage facilities. Vandalism and theft from nurse tanks has

accounted for the some of our releases.



Our employees are trained in the characteristics and proper handling procedures for anhydrous

ammonia. They are equipped with the proper personal protective equipment for routine handling of

the product. The training also covers the basics in responding to emergencies involving ammonia

releases and is available to assist the community first responders with technical information and

advice.



CHS provide training, training material and emergency response information to each fire department

with jurisdiction over our locations. We also meet with concerned citizens and other interested

parties about our risk management program and anhydrous ammonia safety in general.



CHS continually updates the training provided to its employees. Employees are trained in proper

handling, facility inspections, ammonia characteristics; emergency procedures and must review the

emergency response plan, emergency action plan, and site security plan annually.



CHS is proud of its past safety performance and its anhydrous ammonia safety program.
